commands.description: Text editor available on most Unix systems.
examples: vi file1.txt: Edit file1.txt using vi.
vi -R file1.txt: Open file1.txt in read-only mode.
vi +10 file1.txt: Open file1.txt and go to line 10.
vi --version: Display the version of vi.
vi --help: Show help information.

commands.name: echo
commands.description: Display a line of text or a variable value.
examples: echo 'Hello, World!': Print 'Hello, World!' to the terminal.
echo $HOME: Print the value of the HOME environment variable.
echo -n 'Hello': Print 'Hello' without a newline.

echo -e 'Line1
Line2': Enable interpretation of backslash escapes.
echo --help: Show help information.

commands.name: history
examples: history: Show the command history.
history | grep 'command': Search the command history for 'command'.
history -c: Clear the command history.
history -d offset: Delete the command at the specified offset.
history --help: Show help information.

commands.name: clear
examples: clear: Clear the terminal screen.
clear --help: Show help information.

commands.name: pwd
examples: pwd: Display the path of the current working directory.
pwd -L: Print the logical path (following symbolic links).
pwd -P: Print the physical path (resolving symbolic links).
pwd --help: Show help information.

commands.name: du
examples: du: Display the disk usage of the current directory.
du -h: Show disk usage in human-readable format.
du -s /path: Show the total disk usage of /path.
du -a: Display disk usage for all files and directories.
du --help: Show help information.

commands.name: ifconfig
examples: ifconfig: Display information about all network interfaces.
ifconfig eth0: Show information about the eth0 interface.
ifconfig eth0 up: Activate the eth0 interface.
ifconfig eth0 down: Deactivate the eth0 interface.
ifconfig --help: Show help information.

commands.name: ip
commands.description: Show/manipulate routing, devices, policy routing, and tunnels.
examples: ip addr: Display all IP addresses and network interfaces.
ip link set eth0 up: Bring up the eth0 interface.
ip route: Display the routing table.
ip a add 192.168.1.1/24 dev eth0: Add an IP address to eth0.
ip --help: Show help information.

commands.name: netstat
commands.description: Print network connections, routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, and multicast memberships.
examples: netstat: Display a list of network connections.
netstat -t: Show TCP connections.
netstat -u: Show UDP connections.
netstat -r: Show the routing table.
netstat --help: Show help information.

commands.name: traceroute
commands.description: Print the route packets take to the network host.
examples: traceroute example.com: Trace the route to example.com.
traceroute -m 20 example.com: Set the maximum number of hops to 20.
traceroute -n example.com: Show IP addresses only, no domain names.
traceroute --help: Show help information.

commands.name: dig
examples: dig example.com: Perform a DNS lookup for example.com.
dig @8.8.8.8 example.com: Query a specific DNS server.
dig -x 8.8.8.8: Perform a reverse DNS lookup.
dig +short example.com: Show a short format of the DNS response.
dig --help: Show help information.

commands.name: mount
examples: mount /dev/sdX1 /mnt: Mount the device /dev/sdX1 to /mnt.
mount -t ext4 /dev/sdX1 /mnt: Specify the filesystem type (e.g., ext4).
mount -o ro /dev/sdX1 /mnt: Mount the device as read-only.
mount -a: Mount all filesystems mentioned in /etc/fstab.
mount --help: Show help information.
